title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. But I really had to roll my eyes at the story of -year-old Dutch pensioner Emile Ratelband, “who identies as a -year-old” and is fighting to legally change his age by  years so he can get more work and attract more women on Tinder.Emile, above, was born on March , , but says he feels at least  years younger and wants to change his birth date to March , .His argument is thattransgender people are allowed to change sex, he should be allowed to change his date of birth because doctors said he has the body of a -year-old.So does that meanI feel like a supermodel inside, I can I get my job title legally amended Or maybe at  I could identy as  so I can have access to my pension SO the six men arrested for burning an effigy of Grenfell Tower are in hiding and relying on friends and relatives to bring in food and drink. Still, they are yet to speak out – or apologise.What beggars belief is not just that these sick men thought that no one would notice nor care when this footage emerged on social media – but really that they are unhinged enough to do it in the first place.I’m pretty sure about one thing, though. No matter what consequences they will face for their actions from the law, they will never, ever live this down in the eyes of the world – and nor should they.I’m talking about Michael Douglas, . When he was awarded with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for more than  years in the entertainment industry, he gave his father, Kirk, a kiss on the lips to celebrate.In my experience there comes an age when your kids don’t want to kiss you – particularly on the lips and particularly your dad.It’s part and parcel of growing up that your kids don’t even want you to breathe, let alone kiss them.In fact, everything you do embarrasses them. But, given that Kirk Douglas is , maybe it’s just a reminder that things come full circle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. That needs to change. Yet the textbook by itself won’t do that.Soyou’re a parent, politely ask a teacher or headteacherthey got the textbook . . .  and plan to use it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits wont need a visa to travel to europe even if we get a no deal brexit eu confirms
story: UK citizens will be able to visit the EU for up to three months at a time without having to get new documents - eventhere is a No Deal Brexit.The European Commission today unveiled plans for a new visa regime after Britain leaves the EU in March next year.Eurocrats said: The European Commission has today proposed to grant UK citizens visa-free travel to the EU after the United Kingdoms withdrawal from the European Union.It would mean that UK citizens would not need a visa when travelling to the Schengen area for short stays of up to  days in any -day period.Brits who want to work in Europe, or visit for more than three months, may still need to get a visa.And holidaymakers wont be able to use the fast lane at passport control - meaning there could be much longer queues for British people at European airports.The commission also warned that under a No Deal scenario, British driving licences and pet passports could be useless on the continent.The new regime will come into force in four monthsBritain ends up crashing out of the EU without a withdrawal deal.Butwe do get a deal, it will only apply after the end of the transition period which will conclude in December .The EU said that the offer of visa-free travel will be withdrawnthe UK refuses to let Europeans come in without a visa.Theresa May has already promised not to impose visas on holidaymakers from Europe.But it was previously feared the EU would charge Brits £ or more for a permit to enter after Brexit.Todays announcement applies to all the countries of the EU except Ireland, plus Norway, Switzerland, Iceland and Liechtenstein.Freedom of movement between the UK and Ireland is already guaranteed under a separate treaty dating back to .A Government spokesman said: A UK government spokesperson said: We welcome the proposal by the European Commission which reflects the future relationship that the UK wants with the rest of the EU.We have been clear in our proposals that we want to ensure reciprocal measures on visa-free travel for tourists and short term business visitors with the EU.”Anti-Brexit campaigners claimed the new rules will hurt British citizens who spent large parts of the year abroad.Lib Dem MP Tom Brake said: This will come as a real shock to those who spend their winter months in Spain or Portugal and will now see additional costs and potential queues providing extra baggage.

title: brexit deal theresa may leadership vote
story: How could she get booted from No Today Jacob Rees-Mogg openly threatened the Prime Minister to her face, asking her why he should not write a letter directly to the head of the head of the backbenchers.He told Mrs May that what she says and what she does no longer seem to match - and seemed unimpressed with her defence of the deal.He could put in his own letter later today, it was rumoured.The partys backbench chief Graham Brady will have to call a vote of confidence in Mrs May backbenchers request one.Senior Brexiteers from the European Research Group warned on Wednesday night that the threshold for calling a vote of confidence could be passed as soon as today.They insisted there is no co-ordinated plot to unseat the PM - but claimed MPs are so angry that  letters could end up going in anyway.Jacob Rees-Mogg said: The ERG is not trying to force the pace on this but there is the risk of an accident, a lot of people feel very let down and without any organisation might be writing letters.Conor Burns, a close ally of Boris Johnson, told LBC: There’s a lot of febrile talk. What I can tell you is there’s no orchestrated attempt to put letters in.He continued: But sensing the levels of frustration and annoyance colleagues are feeling it would not surprise meorganically letters are going in.The ERG has responded with fury to early reports of Mrs Mays Brexit deal.They claim it will leave the UK tied to the EU permanently thanks to the controversial Irish backstop meant to keep the border open.If Sir Graham, chair of the  Committee, receives  letters asking for a confidence vote, he must hold one within days.Mrs May will be kicked out of powershe fails to win the backing of  of the Tories  MPs.Butshe survives, the party cant hold another vote of confidence for at least a year.Another way Mrs May could be forced out is through a motion of no confidence in the entire government.A ’no confidence’ vote is a formal motion in the House of Commons with the wording: “That this house has no confidence in HM Government.”If there is a vote of no confidence, there will be a two-week ‘cooling off’ period in which time Mrs May will still remain in Downing Street.She will then try and talks to form a new government, butno government can be formed, the prime minister will be forced to call a date for a general election.Of course Mrs May could decide at any time she simply doesnt want to be Prime Minister any more.That will automatically trigger a leadership contest, where Tories will bid to become the next leader and PM.MPs will whittle down the challengers to just  - and those will then be handed over to the Tory membership who will vote and become the next PM.If all of them drop out - like in the summer of  where Mrs May became PM - whoever is left will become leader of the country automatically.They will then go to the Queen and ask permission to form a new government.Mrs May could also be forced out by way of a General election.If two thirds of MPs voted in the House of Commons for a fresh vote, then Parliament would be dissolved and the public would be asked to go to the ballot box yet again.In the event that Labour won more seats than the Tories, Mrs May would automatically be booted from No.If the Tories won the most seats then its likely she would try and form another government - whether on her own or in coalition with another party.Anything is possible in politics right now - even another referendum.If Mrs May decided to call a vote on her deal or No Deal at all, voters could be asked which they would prefer in another Brexit vote.In the event that the Government lost that, Mrs May would almost certainly have to leave office, as David Cameron did in .Today Mrs Mays job hangs by a thread after four ministers including Dominic Raab quit in protest at her deal.She told MPs in the Commons today that her deal was the best on offer, and she believed it was the best thing for the country.But furious MPs are still sending in letters of no confidence in her - and she could be toppled within hours.

title: eu army terrible mistake

title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. But let us see it for what it is.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen elizabeth prince charles tribute birthday
story: The -year-old monarch praised the Prince of Wales as a dedicated and respected heir to the throne in front of a glittering crowd at Buckingham Palace last night.The head of state rarely makes public comments about her children but she used a black-tie dinner staged in Charless honour to praise him as his own man, passionate and creative.Her words were a ringing endorsement of the future king, who has spent a letime in preparation for his role as monarch.Among those at the birthday celebrations were Prince Charles sons Prince William and Harry, with their wives Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle.Raising a glass to honour her son, the Queen told the crowd: Over his  years, Philip and I have seen Charles become a champion of conservation and the arts, a great charitable leader - a dedicated and respected heir to the throne to stand comparison with any in history - and a wonderful father.Most of all, sustained by his we Camilla, he is his own man, passionate and creative.The proud mother said it was a privilege for any mother to see her child toast their th birthday - an honour her own mother had been able to do for her.She said: It means that you have lived long enough to see your child grow up. It is rather like —to use an analogy I am certain will find favour — planting a tree and being able to watch it grow.My mother saw me turn , of course. And she was heard to observe that  is exactly the age when the number of candles on your cake finally exceeds the amount of breath you have to blow them out.And the monarch made sure to keep her speech light as she compared her son to the Duchy Originals - a brand of produce he founded in .The brand - established to sell organic food products - became the UKs largest own-label organic brand.Raising a glass, she said: So this toast is to wish a happy birthday to my son, in every respect a Duchy original.Among those to celebrate Prince Charles at the formal event last night were -year-old dad Prince Philip, as well as Princess Beatrice and newlyweds Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank.Members of royal families across Europe also descended on the palace, with guests including the Crown Princess of Denmark Mary with her husband Frederick.Other guests included Prince Albert of Monaco, Prince Charles niece Zara Tindall, Queen Rania of Jordan, King Harald and Queen Sonja of Norway and Greeces Queen Sophia and Princess Irene.It was the end to a busy day for the Prince of Wales, who had earlier celebrated his th with The Suns remarkable readers.He and we Camilla joined  readers also reaching that age this year to celebrate at our tea party for them.Charles cut a birthday cake, was handed presents and gave an impromptu speech during the event.When the prince arrived for the celebration at Spencer House with Camilla for the event he was asked by the waiting press how he felt.He replied: How am I feeling  Older, older. Im not sure, its rather like indigestion, many happy s are not quite the same thing as you get older.The Prince revealed he has no intention of taking it easy now he has turned .He said: “I was asked outside whether I was going to slow down, I’m not sure I’ve got much alternative but to speed up.”And a new official family portrait was released by the palace to mark Prince Charles birthday, with it a touching nod to the grandfather.The two photos, taken by Chris Jackson and issued by Clarence House, offer a candid insight into the dynamics of the burgeoning family.A raft of solo portraits have also been issued on the occasion of Charles’ signicant birthday – with amazing shots of the Prince from babe, to windsurfer, breakdancer, polo-player and kilt-wearing father, son, husband and grandfather.During a day of tributes to the prince, Theresa May opened a Commons debate to mark the royal birthday and said the heir to the throne had spent his le defying expectations and refusing to be categorised.Mrs May said Charles was often seen to be a man ahead of his time, citing his warnings on pollution, sustainable agriculture and the dehumanising effects of technology in the workplace.Her words were echoed by the Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby in a similar debate in the Lords, when he said the heir to the throne had shown his prophetic instincts in his championing of the environment and his early warnings of the threat posed by plastic pollution.

title: lords vote to scrap four year ban for lib dem peer who told woman shed be a baroness if she slept with him
story: Lords voted  to  to send the case back to a standards committee in an extraordinary move.A watchdog earlier this week ordered the  year-old’s suspension for allegedly telling a women’s rights campaigner “sleep with me and I will make you a baroness”.But peers yesterday complained Lord Lester – suspended by the Lib Dems earlier this year - had been treated unfairly.They said his alleged victim Jasvinder Sanghera had not been cross-examined to test the credibility of her claims – which date back to .Furious Labour MP Jess Phillips last night branded the vote a “disgrace” and called for the abolition of the Upper Chamber.She stormed: “I’m apopletic. They’re going on about procedure but this is all about them telling women like me, ‘We’re above the law and we don’t give a stuff what you think.’ It just says ‘We think we’re better than you’.”The backbencher told The Sun: “If ever there was a time to get rid of the House of Lords, this nails it.”Lord Pannick – a close friend of the disgraced peer – said the standards watchdog had “destroyed” his friend’s reputation.He called on peers to block the suspension – claiming Ms Sanghera had sent Lord Lester a book a week after the alleged harassment signed with “love and admiration”.Lord Lester – dubbed Lord Mo-Lester over the incident – faced a ban until .The Privileges and Conduct Committee will now work out what it does next.Lawyers defending Ms Sanghera pointed out Lords had already accepted the Committee’s role – so couldn’t complain when the decision went against them.The Lib Dems suspended Lord Lester when The Sun revealed the stunning allegations in February. The respected QC - the architect of Britain’s race and sex equality laws - was the Lib Dems Lords spokesman for human rights.Lord McFall, the Lords’ senior deputy speaker, said he was “deeply disappointed” by the vote.He said: “I fully support the Commissioner for Standards and the work she has undertaken for many months.“Every step of the way she followed the processes as agreed by the House and that has not been questioned before today.”He added: “I would also like to express my sympathy to the complainant at what must be a very dficult time for her.”

title: brexit key moments david camerons bloomberg speech lancaster house chequers
story: As we continue to rumble towards the door here are the key dates that have taken us up to where we are now.In January  David Cameron gave what came to be known as the Bloomberg speech.He pledged an in out referendumthe Conservatives won the  election.The then prime minister said he wanted to renegotiate the UKs relationship with the EU and then give people the simple choice between staying in under those new terms, or leaving the EU.Some around Cameron – including George Osborne - are understood to have urged him not to go ahead with the pledge warning that it could have disastrous unintended consequences but he thought it was worth the risk.David Cameron then unexpectedly led the Tories to a majority in .This meant that there was now no way out of agreeing to the referendum he had promised in .After this victory he entered negotiations with the EU to try and get the UK special status within the European Union.He gained a few concessions and decided to campaign for remain, but many in his party were unsatisfied and vowed to campaign to leave.On June rd  Britain voted to leave the European Union in a historic vote.The ultra-narrow margin of victory of % to % left the nation split down the middle and triggered Prime Minister David Camerons resignation.The final result saw ,, Brits vote to leave, while ,, backed remain.David Cameron’s resignation triggered a bloody leadership battle in the Tory party.Boris Johnson was hotly tipped to be a runner but following a shock announcement from Michael Gove that he would be running, BoJo decided not to throw his hat into the ring.Theresa May, Michael Gove, Stephen Crabbe, Andrea Leadsom and Liam Fox all launched bids.But four of the challengers fell away and May eventually rode into Number  unopposed to take the helm of the party and the country.In January  Theresa May spoke to an audience of ambassadors from the EU, and a crowd of journalists, at Lancaster House in London.She outlined a hard Brexit plan for the countrys split from EU institutions.As she laid down what the government wants from negotiations she pledged to build a truly global Britain.She confirmed Britain is to leave the EUs single market and the intention to withdraw from the principle of free movement.She told an audience of EU ambassadors she still intends for the UK to remain close to its friends and allies in the EU but was firm that no deal for Britain is better than a bad deal for Britain.As of .pm on March  , the UK was set on a course to leave the EU by March , .The PM sent an official letter invoking Article  which was delivered to Donald Tusk.It came after Theresa May quashed a Tory revolt after passing a law to authorise Brexit following a marathon five-week battle with Parliament.Article  sets out the process of leaving the EU and states: Any Member State may decide to withdraw from the Union in accordance with its own constitutional requirements.It then goes on to say that a state wishing to withdraw will let the European Council know it intends to leave, which will trigger the article.At this point, the Treaties that bound Britain to EU rules cease to apply and the terms of leaving began to be negotiated.On June   the Tories lost their parliamentary majority in one of the biggest electoral shocks in years.Theresa May opted to call a snap election, a gamble which proved to be a major mistake.Labour made unpredicted gains and the Conservatives were forced to form a minority government with support from the DUP.In September  the PM called for a two year transition period after the UK leaves the EU in .The Prime Minister promised that the UK would continue to pay into the Brussels coffers for that period as part of our orce bill, to ensure we leave no black hole in the EU budget.She also ruled out a hard border in Northern Ireland, saying she “will not accept any physical infrastructure” between the UK and Ireland.After a marathon session of talks at Chequers on July , , Theresa May and her Cabinet managed to hammer out a Brexit plan which she could take to the EU.It saw the UK remain closely tied to Brussels on goods and agriculture, with the creation of a common rulebook.The agreement was met with widespread derision and prompted the resignations of both David Davis and Boris Johnson from the Cabinet.The PM released a  page document on November  with the first details of what leaving the European Union could look like.Most of the items look at what will happen during the agreed transition period which will start on  March  and end on  December  - unless this is extended.The deal was slammed by Brexiteers and prompted a slew of resignations including two Cabinet ministers, Dominic Raab and Esther McVey.DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds also accused Mrs May of breaking her promises in a devastating attack that practically ripped up the deal which props up her GovernmentBut the PM vowed to fight with every fibre of my being hours after Jacob Rees-Mogg pulled the trigger on a Brexiteer rebellion which could see a leadership challenge next week.

title: michel barnier trap britain customs union
story: Brussels’ chief negotiator said the terms of a UK-wide backstop to the Irish border will form the “basis” for the future trade deal.And he warned Theresa May she will have to agree to grant EU fishing vessels access to UK waters infor tarf-free access to the Single Market.The Frenchman made the remarks as he hailed the “crucial step” forward in the talks at a press conference in Brussels last night.He said: “Our objective is to abolish customs duties and quotas for all goods based on what we’re proposing in the Withdrawal Agreement, a single customs territory.“This agreement offers a basis for future negotiations and that is in our common interest.”In a boost for the embattled PM he added that sealing a wide-reaching trade deal is “possible” within the -month transition period.Mr Barnier insisted he was not “self-satisfied or smug” about reaching an agreement despite eurocrats roundly congratulating themselves on the breakthrough.But the comments will infuriate Eurosceptics already furious over a leaked diplomatic note that emerged yesterday from Sabine Weyand, Mr Barnier’s deputy.In it she told ambassadors that Britain had agreed to “level playing field” measures tying Britain to EU rules in areas such as state aid and environmental and workers’ rights protections during a so-called post-Brexit ‘backstop’ or customs fudge.She also said that Britain would “have to swallow a link between access to products and fisheries in future agreements”.EU Commission boss Jean-Claude Juncker last night immediately wrote to his Council counterpart, Donald Tusk, saying “decisive progress” had been achieved.And Danish PM Lars Løkke Rasmussen said: “Green light! Relieved that the UK government has now approved the deal reached by our negotiators. This is decisive for all European citizens and businesses. Hopefully we’ll soon be able to shake hands on a solid agreement.”Meanwhile EU Parliament Brexit chief Guy Verhofstadt added: “This deal is a milestone towards a credible and sustainable future relationship between the EU and the UK.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: minister humiliated after he claims 80 of brits back theresa mays brexit deal then admits he made the number up
story: Challenged by the BBC, Prisons Minister Rory Stewart was forced to admit “producing a number to try to illustrate what I believe”.He added: “Obviously this is not coming from an opinion poll.“I totally apologise for that and I take that back.”Mr Stewart was rumoured to be in the running to replace Esther McVey as Work and Pension Secretary at one stage today.He was one of three ministers pushed out onto the airwaves after the PM’s car crash Commons appearance where she desperately tried to defend her draft Brexit agreement.Speaking to Five Live he stunned presenter Emma Barnett when he insisted eight out of ten voters backed it.He explained: “Sorry, let me get the language right on that, my sense is thatwe have an opportunity to explain this the vast majority of the British public would support this deal.”He added: “I’m just trying to express the basic fact that this is a country that’s in danger of being ided.“But the vast majority of the people are going to be happy with a deal that protects our economy, gives us access on goods right into the market while at the same time giving us control over immigration.“I totally feel thatwe are given an opportunity to calmly explain this deal, many people who are currently worried about it will be reassured.”

title: philip hammond begs businesses brexit call
story: The Chancellor held a conference call with a series of company bosses on Wednesday evening to ask them to publicly support the agreement, alongside Business Secretary Greg Clark.A transcript of the conversation has been leaked to The Sun.During it, Mr Hammond told the bosses: “It would be extremely helpful to hear business voices welcoming the deal and warning against the risk of a no deal approach.“It is essential we repeat and repeat again the logic of pursuing a deal rather than a no deal approach.”Asked by one captain of industry what in particular they should say, the Chancellor replied: “Anything you can do to emphasise the demand a no deal Brexit would do.“Also emphasise that business understands there will be compromise.What matters is that the outcome is infinitely better than the alternative of a no deal.”Mr Hammond added: “We need to create a sense of momentum that will carry this through”.Mr Clark also told the call that their target should be members of the House of Commons who want to vote down Mrs May’s deal in a showdown next month.The Business Secretary added: “MPs need to understand the importance of this for the employees in your firms”.The phone call was said by the Treasury to be just a chance for ministers to explain Mrs May’s deal to business.But the revelation that Mr Hammond and Mr Clark issued specic pleas to them will spark accusations of a new ‘Project Fear’ stitch up by hardline Brexiteers.Chairman of BAE Systems Sir Roger Carr, who was on the call, was one of the first to speak out to back the Government yesterday.Sir Roger told BBC Radio ’s Today Programme: “We have to see this over the line.“We have to play the cards we have not the cards we wished for.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stubborn theresa may geoffrey boycott
story: Two key ministers were among seven to quit over her Brexit agreement.But the PM pledged to bat on, saying: “I believe with every fibre in my body that the course I have set out is the right one.”Askedshe could “deliver the runs” for Britain, Mrs May said: “Can I just say that you might recall from previous comments I have made about cricket that one of my heroes was always Geoffrey Boycott.“And what did you know about Geoffrey Boycott  He stuck to it and got the runs in the end.”Yorkshire ace Boycs scored over , Test runs for England from -.But Mrs May’s innings at No looked doomed last night as her soft Brexit deal faced collapse and a Tory leadership contest loomed.The chaos unfolded after Dominic Raab quit as Brexit Secretary and Esther McVey resigned the Pensions post and accused Mrs May of giving into “blackmail” by the EU. Their departures were followed by five lower-ranking aides.And on a day of high drama:An hour after Mr Raab and Ms McVey announced their exits, Mrs May made a statement in the Commons where she was mauled by MPs on all sides.Mr Rees-Mogg declared war by announcing he had written to the powerful Tory  committee demanding a no-confidence vote.Mr Gove then seemingly turned down the chance to take over as Brexit Secretary with sources saying he would take it onlyhe could renegotiate the current withdrawal deal.But the PM defiantly pledged to carry on in the national interest eventhe compromises involved were not comfortable.She said: “The choice is clear. We can choose to leave with no deal.“We can have no Brexit at all. Or we can choose to unite and support the best deal that can be negotiated.“I choose to deliver for the British people. I choose to do what is in the national interest.”The chaos sent the Pound plunging as markets took fright at the chances of a Brexit deal receding.Rocked by Jacob Rees-Mogg’s bid to replace her with a prominent Leave campaigner, the PM vowed to cling to power even when Tory MPs do manage to trigger a confidence vote in her as party leader.A threshold of  letters demanding one could be reached as early as Friday, with the pivotal vote of all  Tory MPs expected on Monday or Tuesday next week.Even impartial Tories predicted the result could be very tight, with as many as  to  MPs voting against Mrs May or abstaining - making it nigh on impossible for her to carry on.But the PM  signalled last night that she will stay on evenshe wins the vote by a margin of just ONE.When asked that by The Sun, she insisted: “Am I going to see this through  Yes.“Leadership is about taking the right decisions, not the easy ones.”Meanwhile the depth of the crisis that has gripped the Tories became clear when it emerged grandees fear the party will now split apart.The Sun can reveal that emergency planning has already begun for le after Mrs May.Some ministers have initiated  secret talks with moderate Labour MPs for a ‘Government of National Unity’ behind No’s backs as the only hope of ending the Brexit deadlock in the Commons.One mid-ranking minister involved in the clandestine talks told The Sun: “We are speaking to sensible Labour people to see what might be possible.“It’s early days, but we may well end up needing to govern with them when Theresa goes. It really is that bad in my view.”Friends say Mr Davis is ready to take on the jobit comes this side of Christmas.The PM said she was “sorry” so many ministers had decided to go, and admitted some decisions she has had to take to strike an agreement with Brussels were “dficult and sometimes uncomfortable”.But she remained unrepentant about her controversial Brexit deal, which Brexiteers argue leaves Britain tied to EU rules for years after we leave.Mrs May insisted: “I believe with every fibre of my being that the course I have set out is the right one for our country”.But she also issued a thinly veiled warning that funding for schools and hospitals could be slashedMPs reject her deal and the UK spins out without one, saying the UK then faces “a path of deep and grave uncertainty”.The crisis was sparked when Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab revealed he had resigned at .am yesterday – the second Brexit Secretary to go on five months.Furious at the level of dictation that the UK will be forced to take from Brussels under the plan, Mr Raab told The Sun: “I don’t want to submit to the blackmail of my country”.There were also three resignations in the lower ranks, with Anne-Marie Trevelyan and Ranil Jayawardena quitting as PPSs at the Department of Education and the Ministry of Justice, and Rehman Christi quit as a Tory vice chair.Then at pm, hardline Brexiteer leader Mr Rees-Mogg struck, revealing he had handed in his letter of no-confidence in Mrs May to Sir Graham Brady, chairman of the  Committee.A series of other members of the European Research Group faction that he chairs are followed suit, as Mr Rees-Mogg declared: “What we need is a leader who will stand up to the European Union”.But he argued: “Coup is the wrong word. This is entirely constitutional, by the rules of the Conservative Party”.He said he himself would not stand to replace her, but named four potential candidates – Boris Johnson, David Davis, Dominic Raab, and Penny Mordaunt.ERG bosses told The Sun they are unsure they have the numbers to succeed, but still believe a powerful show of force from Brexiteers will sink Mrs May.The PM’s refusal to dump her Brexit deal during tense exchanges in the Commons pushed the MPs over the edge, they said.During an electric three hour-long grilling of Mrs May, ERG vice chair Mark Francois told the PM her deal was “deal on arrival in St Tommys” and pleaded with her “to accept the political reality you face”.Mr Francois claimed  Tory MPs will now vote against her deal, as well as Labour, the DUP, the Lib Dems and the SNP, adding: “It is mathematically impossible to get this deal through the House of Commons”.In another bitter attack on her, DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds told the PM her deal is “a vote for a vassal state to break up the United Kingdom”, and said there was no point in saying more, as “she doesn’t listen”.The Brexiteers’ leadership challenge sparked bitter recriminations from Tory loyalists, and exploded a full-blown civil war in the party.Chief Whip Julian Smith hit back to say Mrs May “will not be bullied”.Foreign office minister Sir Alan Duncan raged: “This is foolhardy, self-indulgent, and wrecking. What’s their alternative “They risk bringing down the Government, destroying the party’s prospects and quite possibly breaking it altogether”Scottish Secretary David Mundell branded Mr Raab “a carpetbagger”, adding of him: “I’m sure this is more about manoeuvring and leadership.Prisons minister Rory Stewart attacked Mr Rees-Mogg and the ERG as “pompous people producing medieval fantasies”.And senior backbencher Bob O’Neill added: “It’s total self-indulgence by my colleagues, they should be ashamed of themselves”.Another senior Tory minister added: “I am now extremely worried about the start of our party. It is being stretched to widely and it is going to break.”Mrs May was Thursday night struggling to replace Mr Raab as his job as well as Ms McVey’s went unfilled overnight.She will be forced to carry out a signicant reshuffle on Friday.Explaining the failing, the PM said: “I have had rather a busy day”.Environment Secretary Michael Gove and Ms Mordaunt both held tough conversations with Mrs May yesterday over their futures, and No aides fear they too could also still resign.The Development Secretary again asked the PM to give all Tory MPs a free vote on her deal when it reaches the Commons.Friends say the PM is considering her request overnight.He has to noty Downing Street within  hours of receiving the th letter.He would call a simple yes no ballot of all  Conservative MPs asking whether the leader should stay.The Sun knew of at least  letters of no confidence from Tories with more expected today.A ballot could be held on Mondaythe  figure is reached by then. A leadership contest would be heldthe PM fails to win a majority — with the target being .Candidates looking to replace Mrs May are likely to include Dominic Raab, Sajid Javid, Jeremy Hunt, Liz Truss, Penny Mordaunt and Boris Johnson. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dominic raab could become next pm
story: The former high-flying lawyer and karate black belt - dubbed one of the “big brains” of the Tory party - quit just  days after being brought into prop up the Government.The MP for Esher and Walton, , was a figurehead for Vote Leave during the  referendum. Mrs May didn’t offer him a job in her new government following the referendum but was drafted in as a Justice Minister a year later after her disastrous  General Election.And a year later he finally got the promotion to Cabinet he had long awaited - drafted in to replace David Davis, who he once served as chief of staff in opposition.Mr Raab’s speech to Tory conference was seen as a leadership pitch - revealing his father escaped from the Holocaust in World War II and vowing to fight anti-Semitism in Jeremy Corbyn’s party until his dying breath.His Czech-born Jewish father escaped to Britain in  as a refugee.Mr Raab, who studied law at Oxford and then Cambridge before becoming a solicitor, is married to a Brazilian marketing executive and the pair live in Thames Ditton in Surrey with their two children.In the  leadership contest Mr Raab initially backed Boris Johnson - but immediately jumped to Michael Gove’s campaign after he withdrew.But after becoming the first Cabinet minister to quit over the Brexit orce deal yesterday, he has put himself in prime position to become the leadership contender Brexiteers can rally around.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: conservative party brexit meltdown dominic raab
story: At am, the Brexit Secretary plunged money markets into a meltdown by announcing he was stepping down.He would soon be followed by Work and Pension Secretary Esther McVey and five others in a day of outright chaos that leaves Theresa May clinging on in No. by her fingertips.What no one realised is that he had made his mind up  hours before - and agreed to delay his resignation as a last personal favour for the PM.Sitting in Cabinet on Wednesday he already knew he would go as he flicked through the  page document that showed his ‘red lines’ had been bartered away in Brussels by Olly Robbins, the PM’s chief Brexit negotiator.“Dom felt totally mugged off by the PM, and who can blame him,” one ally said.The judo-loving Tory stepped into the role in July after his former boss and mentor David Davis had walked out in the wake of Chequers summit - similarly hamstrung by Mrs May’s aides.In his short time in the job Mr Raab was confident he had secured enough “goodies” to make the draft exit deal sell-able to fellow hardline Leavers.But by Tuesday evening he was seething as he realised everything he had fought for had been negotiated away by Robbins.After the marathon five hour Cabinet showdown on Wednesday, designed to bind the PM’s top team into supporting the crucial  page draft deal, he was due to catch the Eurostar.But he was already drafting his resignation letter in his head.Mr Raab had brought his passport, but not packed an overnight bag - sure as he was that there was nothing he could hear around the Cabinet table that would persuade him he could stay on after seeing the final draft on Tuesday night.Tensions amongst Mrs May’s top team had already been stretched for months - with Mr Raab clashing heavily with David Lidington, the head of the Cabinet Office.The silky Remainer stepped up to be the PM’s de facto deputy at Christmas and quickly began to tap into his old contacts as a Foreign Minister to cement relations with the Irish government.As the testy negotiations went to the wire about how to protect the Northern Irish border, Mr Raab’s team felt Mr Lidington, who was in text contact with Irish deputy Simon Coveney, was giving “going behind his back to promise Dublin dferent things”.The day before the critical Cabinet meeting, MPs had Mr Raab had been “strangely chipper” about deal in the pipeline, telling MPs that the terms would acceptable for Brexiteers to back.He had met with junior government aides on the Parliament’s mysterious Lower Whips Corridor - a traditional scene for plotting and intrigue.He told the MPs: “I know expectations are really low, but you’ll be pleasantly surprised.”But some present noticed he always described it as the “PM’s deal” rather than his own work. One attendee said: “I’m really shocked, something changed very late. Dom genuinely appeared to believe people would be relieved when they saw the detail. Then bam, two days later he’s gone.”Later on Tuesday Mr Raab was sent a draft of the Withdrawal Agreement and was left stunned that things he had warned must be included to get the deal through Parliament had been haggled away.Mr Raab had pushed hard for a “unilateral” way of Britain walking away from controversial Irish “backstop”, but instead he found the insurance option that would keep Britain tied to Brussels customs rules for years to come as the basis of a future trade deal, rather than a last resort.And he had seen key parts of the draft future trade deal plan that left the door open to a looser Canada-style deal stripped out in behind closed doors talks with Brussels that he was cut out from.In the final version of the text, all of the things he warned were needed to sell the deal to Brexiteers were gone.When Mrs May’s  strong top team finally got around the table at pm on Wednesday, Mr Raab surprised colleagues – by hardly saying a word.The Prime Minister went around the table, with Mr Raab speaking first, to gauge opinion of dferent Ministers - with  speaking criticising the exit terms.Some thought he was being “weasley” but secretly he had already made his mind up.He was not the only one around the table seething in anger - and his silence was in stark contrast to the anger of Esther McVey.The Work and Pensions Secretary stunned Cabinet colleagues by ripping into the Prime Minister over the “sell-out” and demanded everyone have a vote to register the scale of the rebellion in official minutes. It was swtly denied by the PM’s Cabinet Secretary Mark Sedwill.Pals said Ms McVey had realised she had probably gone too far and decided straight after the showdown that she’d have to go – given relations with No. were already at an all-time low over Universal Credit before the Budget.One ally told The Sun: “She wrote the letter after Cabinet and then fired it off this morning.” They added it was “rubbish” that she was reduced to tears.“Anyone who knows Esther knows that’s cobblers,” the source said. Another cabinet source added: “In a way Esther spoke for us all. We all felt appalling treated and she did not pull her punches.”The first signs of trouble emerged publicly on Wednesday evening after the PM admitted her five hour Cabinet session had been “impassioned”.But behind the black door Mr Raab had taken the Chief Whip aside to tell him he could not tolerate what he was being asked to sign up for.In a bid to calm tensions No had “kettled” Ministers inside No with a glass of “cheap red wine” while the PM addressed the nation - but their bid to sooth tempers failed.By dawn on Thursday it was clear he would not be the only going - his walk out sparking a wave of junior Ministerial departures and finally tipping the Tory right to declare it was time for a new PM.All the resignations followed the same structure, a tweet with a photograph of their letter explaining their reasons. With rolling exits every  minutes throughout the morning, Downing Street insiders began to fear an orchestrated plot.Tory whips were despatched around the sprawling parliamentary estate to sound out whether wavering MPs would back the PM in a looming confidence vote.As the flurry of resignations began to ease, Theresa May’s next headache began.Jacob Rees Mogg gathered  members of the hardline European Research Group bloc of Brexiteers to the grand wood led Committee Room of the House of Commons.After keeping their powder dry for months, the ERG were finally ready to push the button.Ever since the Tories election disaster last June, the group led by Mr Rees Mogg had urged hotheads to bide their time - but now he ruled Mrs May’s time was up.At one point the growing throng of reporters gathered outside was so large the House of Commons doorkeepers had to get police officers to marshal the crowd.Emerging from the room to declare it he was calling for a No Confidence vote, Mr Rees Mogg quipped. were getting into a bit of a bottleneck, like the negotiations.Marching through parliament, with two dozen reporters and TV cameras mobbing him, he insisted he had not launched “a coup” but insisted I am not offering my name as leader.” And the media circus continued outside the grand St Stephens entrance to the House of Commons - the very spot that Theresa May launched her bid to be PM in July .Mr Rees Mogg told the crowd: This is nothing to do with the ambition of Brexiteers. It is everything to do with the ambition of Brexit for this country. But it was clear the hardliners have decided time was up for the PM andthey cannot defeat her, at least they can show Downing Street the have the numbers to defeat her hated Brussels deal.The ERG know that they would only have one shot at taking out the PM and today the name on their lips as a replacement was Dominic Raab.One Brexiteer said: “He’s standing has risen dramatically,these letters go in I wouldn’t put it past us to pick him unanimously as our would-be leader.” And his predecessor in the Brexit Secretary role David Davis told The Sun: “He’s done the right thing.“This deal does not meet either the expectations of the referendum or the promises of the manesto.“No Brexit secretary can stay in place in the face of that. And I should know.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: australian view brexit trade deal
story: There is controlling migration, there is the repatriation of British sovereignty, there is saving billions of pounds a year in payments to the EU, which are mainly spent on subsidising Europe’s archaic agriculture sector and subsidies to the poorer countries of the EU.That money can indeed be erted to propping up the NHS.All those arguments were deployed with gusto during the referendum campaign.But there’s another way of looking at the Brexit issue altogether — and it’s this.Britain is seen by much of the world as the mother of democracy.The mother of democracy held a referendum in June  on whether Great Britain should remain in or leave the European Union.In some countries, that may not have counted for much.If the powerful didn’t like the result, they would have ordered another referendum and kept the masses voting until “they got it right”.We’ve seen that game played from time to time.But in the mother of democracy you would take that vote as a clear demonstration of the democratic will of the people.And once the people have spoken, the powerful are expected to organise things so Britain can make the most of what the people want.That is the commonsense approach.It is not the role of those in high office to frustrate the will of the people.It is their role to make the very most of the people’s will.So let’s think about what would be best for Britain.First and foremost the British Government and the British Parliament should have the flexibility to make economic arrangements which maximise Britain’s economic opportunities.Certainly, it makes sense to maintain free trade with the EU.That shouldn’t be too dficult because there already is free trade with the EU.Common sense tells you that it is neither in Britain’s nor the EU’s interests to erect barriers to trade across the channel.But what being outside the EU allows Britain to do is also make free or freeing trade agreements with other countries.Britain should be able to make free trade agreementswith the most powerful economies in the world.The EU tried and failed to negotiate a trade agreement with the Obama administration, which was, to say the least, a pity.But that is done. Britain should be able to make its own FTA with America, opening that largest of all national markets to free access for British companies.And a free trade agreement with the US would also allow the UK to import American goods at the best available prices.The same applies to China. If Australia can negotiate a free trade agreement with China which gives  per cent of Australian exports to China tarf and quota-free access, then Britain can do the same.Countries such as Japan and Australia are also keen to make free trade agreements with the UK.More than that, both those countries have said they would be delighted to have the UK in the great Asia-Pacic trade arrangement, known as the Trans-Pacic Partnership.That includes  countries from Canada to Australia to Mexico to Singapore.So when you stop to think about it, there is a wealth of opportunities Britain could seize outside the EU, whereasthe UK were to stay in the EU, the EU would negotiate trade agreements on Britain’s behalf.Those agreements,they could be concluded at all, wouldn’t be designed just for the UK they would have to suit all the other  countries of the EU, and we know their interests are often very dferent from Britain’s.The EU sees Brexit as a threat.It fears a liberated Britain would steal a competitive advantage over the EU and that investment, as well as trade, would flow more to Britain’s shores than the EU’s.That, ultimately, is why the EU wants to keep Britain in the customs union.If it does, then Brexit will be no threat the EU will make trade policy for the UK and it will also write Britain’s regulatory requirements.The danger of Theresa May’s agreement with the EU is that it runs the risk of locking Britain into the EU regulatory arrangements and denying Britain the opportunity to negotiate trade agreements.In other words, the UK would gain almost nothing from leaving the EU.On the contrary, it would lose one important thing — the right to have a say over regulations and trade policy.So that’s what all the fuss is about.It would be better to crash out of the EU than be locked indefinitely in the single market and the customs union.Indeed, it would be better to stay in the EU and participate in decision-making than leave but let the EU decide the destiny of British regulations and trade policy. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may remains defiant as she clings on amid brexit turmoil
story: The opening act of yet another dficult day at the crease for Mrs May came when Dominic Raab quit as Brexit secretary, telling the PM her draft Brexit agreement was a "very real threat to the integrity of the United Kingdom" because of its implications for Northern Ireland.Sky News understands Environment Secretary Michael Gove was offered the role of Brexit secretary, but he reportedly rejected it because he would have been unable to go back to Brussels and renegotiate the deal.Mr Raab was followed out of the exit door by Esther McVey, who left her role as work and pensions secretary.:: Brexit agreement: What you need to know She said she could not defend the agreement, which was approved by ministers at a marathon cabinet meeting on Wednesday.Five other Conservative MPs then quit their government or party roles, as the scale of the disquiet at Mrs Mays draft Brexit agreement with Brussels became apparent.More was to follow when Jacob Rees-Mogg, chair of the European Research Group, revealed he had submitted a letter of no-confidence in the PM.:: Tories with the best odds of replacing May He denied suggestions it was the start of a "coup" against Mrs May, but suggested Mr Raab, Ms McVey, former foreign secretary Boris Johnson, former Brexit secretary David Davis and International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt as potential candidates. title: brexit deal summary highlights key
story: NewsBrexit deal summary: Key points from -page document and why Tories are furiousIts the most boring document youll ever read - so weve boiled down what you really need to know from the Brexit agreementShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsIt may be turgid but the draft Brexit deal is vitally important "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May faces a leadership threat after Cabinet ministers agreed the most boring -page document youll ever read. It may be turgid but the draft Brexit deal is vitally important - and itll decidethe Prime Minister is toppled. The agreement is set to be signed off in an EU summit on November . But it could have a huge impact on Northern Ireland businesses and keep the UK locked in the orbit of Brusselsthings go wrong. MPs from hard Tory Brexiteers to Labour have demanded it is voted down when it comes to a crunch decision in Parliament, due within a month. And theyre calling no confidence in the PM. That would throw Brexit back to square one and is likely to remove the flailing Prime Minister from office. So what is in the Brexit deal and why are people so het up about it  Weve taken a closer look.  Weve signed up to a transition period that will continue pretty much all EU rules until December . Now this could be extended - and crucially, we dont yet know how long for. The deal only covers to the year xx. Which to put it mildly is a bit vague. Senior officials insist that by the time MPs have a vote, therell be a maximumof extra transition - which would then be whittled down further. But its likely to prompt a huge row. The transition period can only be extended once. And it would be done by the UK making a request before  June . This request would be considered by an arbitration . That  would have  UK members,  EU members and  independent member, chosen through a legal process. We dont know who theyd be. Eventhe transition period is extended we could still end up in a backstop. For more on that, read on...  Under the backstop - a backup plantheres no agreement for the Northern Ireland border - there COULD be checks on some goods between Northern Ireland and the UK. Theresa Mays DUP allies say this is unacceptable and its likely to prompt a huge row. Northern Ireland firms will access the EU Single Market as a whole without restriction. This will mean Northern Ireland will have to apply EU law on industrial, environmental and agricultural goods. That means some of these goods would need checks between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.  The backstop -it kicks in on  January  - will extend EU customs rules across the whole of the UK. This makes Brexiteers furious because it will stop us signing trade deals with the rest of the world - and lock us into Brussels rules without any say on them. Whats worse, we can only quit the backstopthere is mutual agreement between the UK and the EU. Senior UK officials insisted the EU would have to act in good faith. But thatll be cold comfort to Tory Brexiteers. European courts will still have a big hold on the UK  Any judgements from the European Court of Justice handed down during the transition period will be binding on the UK. And the arbitration  that resolves disputeswill not intervene in cases involving EU law. Instead the European Court of Justice will rule on those questions. And we still have a long way to go...  Senior UK officials tonight admitted there is still a lot of negotiation to go. The UK has now unlocked negotiations on the so-called future framework for a deal that can lead to trade after Brexit. They are trying to get parts of that closed off before MPs have their meaningful vote in Parliament. So sit tight - theres a very long way still left to run.
